bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Manager, Southern Power Company, October 7, 1922

div1.p: Carter reports on his survey of McDowell Creek to determine the presence of malaria bearing mosquitoes and the effect of the proposed Mountain Island Pond on the production of these mosquitoes. Carter believes a survey needs to be repeated after the creation of the pond.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Manager, Southern Power Company, October 7, 1922
div1.opener:
Copy sent to
Dr. Fricks with
a long letter
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
October 7, 1922.
N. M. C
I. Water
Southern P. C,
Manager,
Southern Power Company,
Charlotte, N. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
While at Charlotte recently I made a survey of so much of the
valley of McDowell Creek as will be flooded by the purposed Mountain
Island Pond and of its environment within something over a mile of
this flowage line. This survey was made to determine (1) the produc-
tion of Anopheles (malaria bearing) mosquitoes in the area surveyed and
(2), as far as may be, the effect of the pond when filled upon such
production. The end sought being to attempt to form an idea of what
will be the effect of the pond on the incidence of malaria and to,
so far as may be, minimize this production.

I understand that you had requested Dr. Barrett of Charlotte and
Dr. Boldridge of Chester (both of whom accompanied me on this survey)
to undertake a complete survey of the flowage area of the pond and, I
presume, its environment, within a reasonable distance.

This both of these gentlemen inform me they are unable to under-
take as it would take them too completely from their present business,
but are willing, indeed desireous, of working in assistance of some
competent man who could give sufficient time to the job.

Under these circumstances I would ask if you would like to have
this survey made by the Malaria Division of the Public Health Service.
Service.
2.
I do not know if this Service is prepared to undertake this work for
you or not--it should begin next spring. If you so wish, you can get
information on this point from
Surgeon L. D. Fricks, U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17, Court House Building,
Memphis, Tenn.

This survey to be complete is rather an extensive affair. It should
determine the Anopheles production of the flowage area and environment be-
fore the pond is filled, going over the ground as many times as neces-
sary; and the same class of survey--of the Pond itself and environment--
after the pond is filled for--say--the first two or three years and at in-
tervals thereafter.

It would require a competent man and at least one as-
sistant most of the time during the Anopheles breeding seasons of 1923 and
1924, and at intervals later.

The surveys made hitherto by the Public Health Service have been at
its own expense and I judge this would be the case if Dr. Fricks under-
took this one. If it be found advisable for either Dr. Barrett or Dr.
Boldridge to assist occasionally in any manner, I presume that the Com-
pany would wish to reimburse them for their services.

A survey of the kind instanced, planned by myself, was begun of
your pond at Fishing Creek, by LePrince and Griffitts, in 1916, but ow-
ing to the war was never completed.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
